Normalde kalsiyumu içeride tutan özel kanallar ve proteinlerdeki değişiklikler nedeniyle kalsiyumun SR'den sızdığını buldular. Ekip ayrıca fareleri BuOE ile tedavi etmenin—egzersizin bazı faydalarını taklit eden bir ilaç—bu kalsiyum sızıntısını önleyip önleyemeyeceğini test etti. Şaşırtıcı bir şekilde, BuOE tedavisi sorunu çözmedi.
content.advanced: Bu araştırma, sarkoplazmik retikulum (SR) kalsiyum homeostazında mikro yerçekiminin neden olduğu değişiklikleri aydınlatmakta ve antioksidan özelliklere sahip bir katalaz mimetiği olan butil oksamin etil ester'in (BuOE) karşı tedbir olarak etkinliğini değerlendirmektedir. Erkek C57BL/6 fareler, Bion-M1 biyosatellitinde 30 günlük uzay uçuşu geçirmiş veya yer tabanlı arka bacak boşaltma sırasında BuOE tedavisi (osmotik minipompa yoluyla 150 mg/kg/gün) almıştır. Birincil uç noktalar şunları içeriyordu: (1) Dinlenme koşulları altında geçirgen kas liflerinde Fluo-4 kalsiyum görüntüleme kullanarak SR Ca2+ sızıntı ölçümleri; (2) [3H]ryanodin bağlanma kinetiği yoluyla değerlendirilen Ryanodin reseptör tip 1 (RyR1) fonksiyonu; (3) Oksidasyon (protein karbonilasyonu, S-glutatilasyon), nitrozilasyon (S-nitrozilasyon) ve fosforilasyon durumu dahil olmak üzere RyR1 translasyon sonrası modifikasyonlar; (4) Ko-immünopresipitasyon ile ölçülen RyR1'e kalstabin1 (FKBP12) bağlanması; (5) SR Ca2+ ATPaz (SERCA) aktivitesi ve ifadesi; (6) Orai1/STIM1 aktivasyonu yoluyla depo tarafından işletilen kalsiyum girişi (SOCE).

title: Cardiovascular progenitor cells cultured aboard the International Space Station exhibit altered developmental and functional properties
author: Sylvain V. C., et al.

content.beginner: Stem cells have the potential to develop into many different cell types, including heart cells. This study examined what happens to cardiovascular progenitor cells—early-stage cells that can become various types of heart and blood vessel cells—when they're grown in space. Researchers sent these cells to the International Space Station for 30 days and then compared them to identical cells grown on Earth. The space-grown cells showed significant differences: they multiplied more slowly, their shape changed, and they didn't develop into mature heart cells as efficiently. When tested for their ability to contract like heart muscle, the space cells were weaker. Gene expression analysis revealed that hundreds of genes were turned on or off differently in space, affecting cell development, metabolism, and stress responses. Interestingly, the cells showed signs of premature aging. These findings are important for understanding cardiovascular health risks during long space missions and could also provide insights into heart disease and regenerative medicine here on Earth.
content.advanced: This investigation characterizes the impact of authentic microgravity exposure on human cardiovascular progenitor cells (CPCs) cultured aboard the International Space Station for 30 days, employing comprehensive phenotypic, functional, and molecular profiling to elucidate spaceflight effects on cardiac regenerative cell populations. Human CPCs isolated from adult atrial appendage biopsies (c-Kit+/CD90+/CD105+ phenotype, representing multipotent cardiac mesenchymal progenitors capable of cardiomyogenic, endothelial, and smooth muscle differentiation) were expanded ex vivo and loaded into specialized CellBox-3 hardware providing automated media exchange, temperature control, and fixation capabilities. Flight samples (n=6 biological replicates) were cultured under standard conditions (37°C, 5% CO2) in DMEM+10% FBS for 30 days, with parallel ground controls (n=6) in identical hardware under 1g conditions. Post-flight analyses included: (1) Proliferation kinetics via population doubling calculations and EdU incorporation; (2) Flow cytometry immunophenotyping for stem cell markers (c-Kit, Sca-1, CD90, CD105) and differentiation markers (cardiac troponin I, smooth muscle actin, CD31); (3) Morphological assessment via phase-contrast and immunofluorescence microscopy; (4) Directed cardiomyogenic differentiation using 5-azacytidine followed by functional contractility measurements; (5) RNA-sequencing transcriptome profiling (Illumina HiSeq, >50 million reads/sample); (6) Proteomics via tandem mass spectrometry; (7) Mitochondrial function assessment (oxygen consumption rates, membrane potential, ROS production); (8) Senescence markers (β-galactosidase staining, p16/p21 expression, telomere length). Proliferation analysis revealed that spaceflight CPCs exhibited 38% reduced proliferation rate compared to ground controls (population doubling time 42.3 hours versus 30.8 hours, p<0.01), associated with 28% reduction in EdU+ cells indicating decreased S-phase entry. Cell cycle analysis demonstrated G0/G1 arrest with 62% of flight cells in G0/G1 versus 48% controls (p<0.01). Morphologically, spaceflight CPCs displayed altered cytoskeletal organization with 45% reduction in F-actin stress fiber density, increased cell area (1.6-fold, p<0.01) suggesting flattened morphology, and disrupted focal adhesion complexes (vinculin, paxillin clustering reduced 52%). Stem cell marker expression was partially compromised: c-Kit expression decreased 25% at protein level, while CD105 remained stable. Critically, cardiomyogenic differentiation capacity was impaired: following 5-azacytidine induction, flight-origin CPCs showed 43% reduction in troponin I+ cardiomyocyte yield (18.2% versus 31.9% in controls, p<0.001). Spontaneously contracting cell clusters were observed in only 22% of flight cultures versus 67% of control cultures. Calcium transient analysis of differentiated cardiomyocytes revealed 35% reduced amplitude and irregular kinetics in flight-derived cells. RNA-seq identified 2,847 differentially expressed genes (DEGs, FDR<0.05, |log2FC|>1) with Gene Ontology enrichment revealing downregulated pathways including: 'cardiac muscle development' (58 genes, p<10-12), 'cell adhesion' (142 genes), 'extracellular matrix organization' (89 genes), 'Wnt signaling' (38 genes critical for cardiac specification), and 'mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation' (67 genes). Upregulated pathways included: 'response to oxidative stress' (78 genes), 'inflammatory response' (94 genes), 'apoptosis' (52 genes), and 'cellular senescence' (43 genes). Key transcription factors governing cardiac development showed altered expression: NKX2.5 (master cardiac transcription factor) downregulated 1.8-fold, GATA4 decreased 1.4-fold, MEF2C decreased 1.6-fold, while pro-fibrotic factors (TGFβ1, collagens) increased. Proteomics validated transcriptomic findings with 412 differentially abundant proteins, notably including reduced sarcomeric proteins (troponins, myosins, actins) and increased stress response proteins (HSPs, antioxidant enzymes). Mitochondrial functional assessment revealed 47% reduced maximal respiratory capacity, 32% decreased ATP-linked respiration, 2.3-fold elevated ROS production, and 25% reduced mitochondrial membrane potential, indicating mitochondrial dysfunction potentially driving impaired differentiation. Senescence analyses provided striking findings: β-galactosidase+ senescent cells increased from 8% in controls to 31% in flight samples (p<0.001), p16INK4a expression increased 3.2-fold, p21CIP1 increased 2.4-fold, and telomere length decreased by average 18% (q-PCR telomere/single copy gene ratio). Mechanistic investigations implicated multiple contributing factors: (1) Loss of mechanical stimulation eliminates integrin-mediated mechanotransduction (FAK, Src, YAP/TAZ signaling) critical for maintaining stem cell 'stemness' and directing lineage commitment; (2) Altered fluid dynamics and mass transport in microgravity disrupt paracrine signaling and morphogen gradients; (3) Microgravity-induced cytoskeletal remodeling affects nuclear shape and chromatin organization, influencing epigenetic landscapes and transcription factor accessibility; (4) Mitochondrial dysfunction generates oxidative stress promoting senescence; (5) Dysregulated autophagy (LC3-II/I ratio decreased 38%) impairs quality control mechanisms. Validation studies using rotating wall vessel bioreactors (simulated microgravity) partially recapitulated phenotypes (~60% of spaceflight effects), confirming microgravity as primary causative factor while suggesting additional spaceflight-specific factors (cosmic radiation, trace contaminants) contribute. The research has dual implications: (1) Space medicine – cardiovascular risks during long-duration missions may include impaired cardiac repair capacity, as endogenous CPCs show compromised regenerative potential; astronauts recovering from cardiac events in space may face reduced healing capacity; (2) Terrestrial regenerative medicine – microgravity culture could serve as model system for studying aging-associated CPC dysfunction; insights into mechanotransduction requirements inform biomaterial scaffold design for tissue engineering. Potential countermeasures include pharmacological interventions targeting identified pathways (e.g., Rho/ROCK activators to restore cytoskeletal tension, NAD+ precursors for mitochondrial function, senolytics to eliminate senescent cells) or physical interventions (centrifugation providing artificial gravity, mechanical stimulation platforms).

tr.title: Uluslararası Uzay İstasyonu'nda Kültürlenen Kardiyovasküler Progenitor Hücreler, Değişmiş Gelişimsel ve Fonksiyonel Özellikler Sergiler
tr.author: Sylvain V. C. ve ark.

content.beginner: Kök hücrelerin kalp hücreleri dahil olmak üzere birçok farklı hücre tipine gelişme potansiyeli vardır. Bu çalışma, uzayda yetiştirildiğinde kardiyovasküler progenitor hücrelere—çeşitli kalp ve kan damarı hücre tiplerine dönüşebilen erken aşama hücrelere—ne olduğunu incelemiştir. Araştırmacılar bu hücreleri 30 günlüğüne Uluslararası Uzay İstasyonu'na gönderdiler ve ardından onları Dünya'da yetiştirilen aynı hücrelerle karşılaştırdılar. Uzayda yetişen hücreler önemli farklılıklar gösterdi: daha yavaş çoğaldılar, şekilleri değişti ve olgn kalp hücrelerine verimli bir şekilde gelişmediler. Kalp kası gibi kasılma yetenekleri test edildiğinde uzay hücreleri daha zayıftı. Gen ifade analizi, yuz lerce genin uzayda farklı şekilde açıldığını veya kapandığını ortaya çıkardı.
content.advanced: Bu araştırma, Uluslararası Uzay İstasyonu'nda 30 gün boyunca kültürlenen insan kardiyovasküler progenitor hücreleri (CPC'ler) üzerinde gerçek mikro yerçekimi maruziyetinin etkisini karakterize etmekte, kardiyak rejeneratif hücre popülasyonları üzerindeki uzay uçuşu etkilerini aydınlatmak için kapsamlı fenotipik, fonksiyonel ve moleküler profilleme kullanmaktadır. Yetişkin atriyal apendiks biyopsilerinden izole edilen insan CPC'leri (c-Kit+/CD90+/CD105+ fenotipi, kardiyomiyojenik, endotelyal ve düz kas farklılaşması yapabilen multipotent kardiyak mezenkimal progenitorleri temsil eder) ex vivo genişletilmiş ve otomatik ortam değişimi, sıcaklık kontrolü ve sabitleme yetenekleri sağlayan özel CellBox-3 donanımına yüklenmiştir. Uçuş örnekleri (n=6 biyolojik tekrar), DMEM+%10 FBS'de standart koşullarda (37°C, %5 CO2) 30 gün boyunca kültür edilmiş ve 1g koşullarında aynı donanımda paralel yer kontrolleri (n=6) yapılmıştır.

title: Inter-agency perspective: Translating advances in biomarker discovery and medical countermeasures development between terrestrial and space radiation environments
author: Heath W. M., et al.

content.beginner: Radiation exposure is a major concern both for astronauts in space and for people receiving radiation therapy on Earth. This collaborative review brings together experts from NASA, Department of Energy, and medical institutions to discuss how research findings can be shared between space radiation science and cancer radiation medicine. Scientists have identified biomarkers—measurable biological indicators like specific proteins or DNA changes that appear after radiation exposure. These biomarkers help predict who will develop radiation sickness and how severe it will be. The review discusses how biomarkers discovered in one field can benefit the other: for example, biomarkers identifying space radiation damage might help predict cancer treatment side effects, while countermeasures developed for radiation therapy (protective drugs, gene therapies) might protect astronauts. The key challenge is that space radiation (high-energy cosmic particles) is very different from medical radiation (X-rays, gamma rays), but both cause DNA damage and inflammation. By working together across agencies and disciplines, scientists can accelerate development of both better radiation protection for astronauts and improved cancer treatments for patients on Earth.
content.advanced: This comprehensive inter-agency white paper synthesizes perspectives from NASA's Human Research Program, Department of Energy national laboratories, National Cancer Institute, and academic radiation biology centers to establish translational frameworks for bidirectional knowledge exchange between space radiation research and terrestrial radiation medicine. The document addresses fundamental question: How can biomarker discovery and medical countermeasure (MCM) development in one radiation domain inform and accelerate progress in the other? Space radiation environment differs fundamentally from therapeutic/accidental terrestrial exposures: galactic cosmic rays (GCR) comprise ~1% high-energy protons, ~87% helium nuclei, ~12% HZE particles (Z>2) with kinetic energies 100 MeV/n to >10 GeV/n; solar particle events (SPE) deliver primarily low-energy protons (10-100 MeV); trapped radiation belts contain electrons and protons. Terrestrial radiation medicine primarily employs low-LET photons (X-rays, gamma rays, 0.2-2 keV/μm) or in some cases high-LET particles (proton therapy, carbon ion therapy). Despite physical differences, both induce DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs), oxidative stress, inflammation, and tissue injury through partially overlapping mechanisms, creating opportunities for translation. BIOMARKER DISCOVERY: The review catalogs validated and candidate biomarkers across multiple categories: (1) DNA damage biomarkers: γ-H2AX (phosphorylated histone variant marking DSBs), 53BP1 foci (DSB repair protein), dicentric chromosomes (classic cytogenetic aberration), micronuclei frequency, telomere dysfunction-induced foci; (2) Oxidative stress markers: 8-oxo-dG (oxidized DNA base), protein carbonyls, F2-isoprostanes, glutathione:GSSG ratio; (3) Inflammatory markers: cytokine panels (IL-6, IL-8, TNF-α, TGF-β), C-reactive protein, serum amyloid A; (4) Metabolomic signatures: altered amino acid profiles (citrulline decrease indicating GI damage), lipid mediators (ceramides, sphingosine-1-phosphate), TCA cycle intermediates; (5) Proteomic signatures: acute phase proteins (haptoglobin, ceruloplasmin), growth factors (FGF, VEGF), matrix metalloproteinases; (6) Gene expression signatures: peripheral blood transcriptomic panels (radiation responsive genes including FDXR, DDB2, PCNA, GADD45A), microRNA profiles (miR-34a, miR-21); (7) Cell-free DNA and circulating tumor cells (for cancer patients). Case studies demonstrate bidirectional translation: NASA-funded studies identifying miR-150 downregulation as consistent radiation response signature informed its evaluation in predicting radiotherapy normal tissue toxicity; conversely, clinical discovery of plasma citrulline as GI radiation injury biomarker enabled its adoption for monitoring astronaut GI health. Validation challenges include: dose-response relationships differ between acute high-dose terrestrial exposures versus chronic low-dose-rate space exposures; individual variability ('radiosensitivity phenotypes') affects biomarker kinetics; sample collection/storage constraints in space; need for minimally-invasive samples (blood, saliva, urine) rather than tissue biopsies. MEDICAL COUNTERMEASURES: The document systematically evaluates MCM classes: (1) Radioprotectors (administered before exposure): amifostine (FDA-approved for xerostomia prevention) reduces oxidative damage but has significant side effects limiting space use; newer agents include MnSOD mimetics, antioxidant cocktails, Toll-like receptor agonists (CBLB502); (2) Radiomitigators (during/early post-exposure): growth factors (G-CSF, GM-CSF, TPO analogs) stimulate hematopoietic recovery; 5-androstenediol modulates inflammatory responses; (3) Radiosensitizers (cancer-specific, not applicable to space protection); (4) Regenerative biologics: mesenchymal stem cells for tissue repair, exosomes containing protective microRNAs; (5) Gene therapy approaches: p53 restoration, antioxidant enzyme overexpression, DNA repair enhancement. Translation success story: AT2-receptor antagonist developed for cardiac radioprotection showed efficacy in preclinical models of space radiation-induced CNS damage. Key barriers include: regulatory pathways differ (FDA for medicines versus NASA safety standards), endpoint differences (cancer control/survival versus operational performance), cost-effectiveness calculations vary dramatically. DOSE RECONSTRUCTION AND BIODOSIMETRY: Both fields require accurate dose assessment: space missions need cumulative organ dose monitoring for risk projection; radiation accidents need rapid triage. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) of teeth/bone, optically stimulated luminescence of electronics, and biological dosimetry (dicentric assay, cytokinesis-block micronucleus, γ-H2AX kinetics) provide complementary approaches. Emerging techniques include gene expression-based dose reconstruction algorithms with machine learning achieving ±0.3 Gy accuracy. MECHANISMS AND RISK MODELING: Both communities employ Linear Energy Transfer (LET)-based modeling but frameworks differ: NASA uses Quality Factors and RBE derived from carcinogenesis data; medical physics uses clinical RBE values (typically 1.1 for protons, 2-3 for carbons). Systems biology approaches integrating 'omics data with mechanistic models (e.g., NASA's GUI-FLY particle track model linking physical energy deposition to biological outcomes) could bridge these frameworks. NON-TARGETED EFFECTS: Recognition that radiation effects extend beyond directly-hit cells (bystander effects, abscopal effects, genomic instability transmitted to progeny) creates convergent research opportunities. Exosomal signaling, inflammatory cascades, and epigenetic modifications mediate these effects in both contexts. PROGRAMMATIC RECOMMENDATIONS: (1) Establish joint funding mechanisms (NASA-NCI-DOE) for bidirectional translation studies; (2) Create shared biorepositories storing samples from space missions and radiotherapy patients with linked clinical data; (3) Harmonize assay protocols enabling cross-study comparisons; (4) Develop common data standards and informatics infrastructure; (5) Conduct comparative studies directly testing same agents in space-relevant HZE exposures and clinical scenarios; (6) Train next-generation researchers across both domains. The synthesis concludes that while challenges exist, strategic coordination can accelerate biomarker validation, expand MCM pipelines, and ultimately improve both astronaut safety and cancer patient outcomes, exemplifying translational science at the intersection of exploration medicine and precision oncology.

tr.title: Kurumlar Arası Bakış Açısı: Biyobelirteç Keşfi ve Tıbbi Karşı Tedbir Geliştirmedeki İlerlemelerin Karasal ve Uzay Radyasyon Ortamları Arasında Tercüme Edilmesi
tr.author: Heath W. M. ve ark.

content.beginner: Radyasyona maruziyet hem uzaydaki astronotlar hem de Dünya'da radyasyon tedavisi alan insanlar için büyük bir endişedir. Bu işbirlikçi derleme, uzay radyasyon bilimi ile kanser radyasyon tıbbı arasında araştırma bulgularının nasıl paylaşılabileceğini tartışmak için NASA, Enerji Bakanlığı ve tıbbi kurumlardan uzmanları bir araya getirmektedir. Bilim insanları biyobelirteçler—radyasyon maruziyetinden sonra ortaya çıkan belirli proteinler veya DNA değişiklikleri gibi ölçülebilir biyolojik göstergeler—tanımlamışlardır. Bu biyobelirteçler, kimin radyasyon hastalığı geliştireceğini ve bunun ne kadar şiddetli olacağını tahmin etmeye yardımcı olur. Derleme, bir alanda keşfedilen biyobelirteçlerin diğerine nasıl fayda sağlayabileceğini tartışıyor.
content.advanced: Bu kapsamlı kurumlar arası beyaz kitap, uzay radyasyon araştırması ile karasal radyasyon tıbbı arasında çift yönlü bilgi alışverişi için tercüme çerçeveleri oluşturmak amacıyla NASA'nın İnsan Araştırma Programı, Enerji Bakanlığı ulusal laboratuvarları, Ulusal Kanser Enstitüsü ve akademik radyasyon biyolojisi merkezlerinden perspektifleri sentezlemektedir. Belge temel soruyu ele alıyor: Bir radyasyon alanındaki biyobelirteç keşfi ve tıbbi karşı tedbir (MCM) geliştirme diğerindeki ilerlemeyi nasıl bilgilendirebilir ve hızlandırabilir? Uzay radyasyon ortamı, terapötik/kazara karasal maruziyetlerden temelden farklıdır: galaktik kozmik ışınlar (GCR), ~%1 yüksek enerjili protonlar, ~%87 helyum çekirdekleri, ~%12 HZE parçacıkları (Z>2) 100 MeV/n ile >10 GeV/n kinetik enerjileri içerir; güneş parçacık olayları (SPE) öncelikle düşük enerjili protonlar (10-100 MeV) sağlar; tuzaklı radyasyon kuşakları elektronlar ve protonlar içerir.

title: Genomic and functional characterization of Enterococcus faecalis isolates recovered from the International Space Station and their potential for pathogenicity
author: Sheila C. C., et al.

content.beginner: Bacteria live everywhere, even in space stations. Enterococcus faecalis is a type of bacteria commonly found in human intestines that can cause infections, especially in people with weakened immune systems. Scientists collected bacterial samples from various surfaces aboard the International Space Station to see what microbes were living there and whether they posed health risks. They found several strains of E. faecalis and used DNA sequencing to analyze their genetic makeup. Concerningly, these space station bacteria carried genes for antibiotic resistance, making them harder to treat with common medicines. They also possessed virulence factors—genetic tools that help bacteria cause disease—including genes for biofilm formation (allowing bacteria to stick to surfaces and resist cleaning), toxin production, and immune system evasion. Laboratory tests showed the ISS strains could survive harsh conditions and were just as capable of causing infections as hospital strains on Earth. This research highlights the importance of monitoring microbial populations in closed spacecraft environments to protect astronaut health during long missions.
content.advanced: This comprehensive genomic and phenotypic investigation characterizes Enterococcus faecalis strains isolated from environmental surfaces aboard the International Space Station over multiple expeditions, employing whole-genome sequencing, comparative genomics, antimicrobial susceptibility testing, virulence factor profiling, and infection model assays to assess pathogenic potential and implications for crew health. E. faecalis is a Gram-positive facultative anaerobe, a commensal of human GI tract but also an opportunistic pathogen responsible for 10-15% of nosocomial infections including urinary tract infections, bacteremia, endocarditis, and wound infections. Environmental surveillance of ISS collected surface swabs from high-touch areas (handrails, exercise equipment, crew quarters, waste management system) during Expeditions 24-48, with samples cultured and species identified via 16S rRNA sequencing and MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry. Five E. faecalis isolates were selected for comprehensive characterization (ISS-EF01 through ISS-EF05). Whole-genome sequencing employed Illumina HiSeq (150 bp paired-end reads, >100X coverage) with de novo assembly using SPAdes, yielding genomes of 2.95-3.12 Mb with 2,850-3,020 predicted ORFs. Comparative genomic analysis against 47 reference E. faecalis genomes (hospital-acquired, community-acquired, commensal strains) used OrthoMCL for ortholog clustering and BLAST-based virulence factor/antibiotic resistance gene identification against VFDB and CARD databases. Phylogenomic analysis using core genome SNPs positioned ISS isolates within the broad E. faecalis population structure, showing closest relatedness to hospital-associated lineages (clonal complex CC2, CC9) rather than commensal strains, suggesting possible introduction via crew members with prior healthcare exposures or contamination from terrestrial manufacturing facilities. Antimicrobial susceptibility testing (AST) via broth microdilution per CLSI guidelines revealed concerning resistance profiles: all five ISS isolates demonstrated resistance to tetracycline (MIC >16 μg/mL), erythromycin (MIC >8 μg/mL), and ciprofloxacin (MIC >4 μg/mL); three isolates showed high-level gentamicin resistance (HLGR, MIC >500 μg/mL); importantly, all retained vancomycin susceptibility (MIC ≤2 μg/mL, no VRE). Resistance gene analysis identified: tetM (tetracycline efflux), ermB (macrolide resistance methylase), gyrA/parC point mutations (quinolone resistance), aac(6')-Ie-aph(2'')-Ia (aminoglycoside modifying enzyme conferring HLGR). Notably, ISS isolates harbored mobile genetic elements including ICE (integrative conjugative elements) of Tn916 family potentially enabling horizontal resistance gene transfer. Virulence factor profiling identified key pathogenicity determinants: (1) Adhesion factors: esp (enterococcal surface protein, 100% prevalence), ace (collagen adhesin), efaA (endocarditis antigen); (2) Biofilm formation: extensive biofilm production capacity assessed via crystal violet assay showed ISS isolates produced biofilms 1.6-2.3X greater than reference strain OG1RF (p<0.01), correlating with elevated esp expression; confocal microscopy revealed mature biofilms with extensive extracellular matrix and 3D tower structures resistant to detergent disruption; (3) Cytotoxins: cylA (cytolysin operon) present in 3/5 isolates with hemolytic activity confirmed on blood agar; gelE (gelatinase metalloprotease) present in 4/5 isolates with proteolytic activity; (4) Stress resistance: ISS isolates exhibited enhanced tolerance to osmotic stress (growth in 6.5% NaCl), oxidative stress (10 mM H2O2 survival 2.1X higher than reference), desiccation (survival on dry surfaces 28 days), and UV radiation (D10 values 1.8X higher); (5) Immune evasion: capsular polysaccharide production, catalase activity (unusual for E. faecalis). In vivo pathogenicity was assessed using Galleria mellonella (wax moth) infection model: ISS isolates caused dose-dependent mortality with LD50 values (2.3-4.1 X 10^5 CFU/larva) comparable to clinical isolates, confirming retained virulence. Murine peritonitis model (subset testing) demonstrated ISS-EF02 caused lethal infections with bacterial loads in spleen/liver equivalent to hospital strain V583. Importantly, space environment may select for enhanced stress tolerance: comparative analysis of ISS isolates versus genetically-similar terrestrial strains revealed that ISS bacteria exhibited significantly elevated biofilm formation (1.4X, p<0.05) and desiccation survival (1.6X, p<0.01), suggesting adaptation to ISS conditions (low humidity, frequent cleaning with quaternary ammonium compounds, UV exposure from windows). Mechanistic investigations revealed upregulated stress response genes including clpP (caseinolytic protease), dnaK (heat shock protein), and two-component regulatory systems (liaRS, ciaRH). Horizontal gene transfer potential was demonstrated via conjugation experiments: ISS isolates successfully transferred tetM-containing Tn916 ICE elements to recipient E. faecalis strains at frequencies of 10^-6 to 10^-5 transconjugants/donor, indicating capability for resistance dissemination within mixed microbial communities. The findings raise several crew health concerns: (1) Antibiotic-resistant opportunistic pathogens persist in ISS environment despite cleaning protocols; (2) Enhanced stress tolerance may enable bacterial survival in harsh spacecraft conditions; (3) Compromised astronaut immunity due to spaceflight stressors increases infection susceptibility; (4) Limited antibiotic formulary aboard ISS means multi-drug resistant infections are challenging to treat; (5) Biofilm formation on life support equipment could cause system malfunctions. Recommendations include: enhanced molecular surveillance of ISS microbiome, optimization of cleaning protocols specifically targeting biofilms, probiotic countermeasures to outcompete pathobionts, prebiotic surface coatings preventing bacterial adhesion, contingency planning for antibiotic-resistant infections, and research into novel antimicrobials (bacteriophages, antimicrobial peptides) suitable for space medicine applications.

tr.title: Uluslararası Uzay İstasyonu'ndan Kurtaralılan Enterococcus Faecalis İzolatlarının Genomik ve Fonksiyonel Karakterizasyonu ve Patojenite Potansiyelleri
tr.author: Sheila C. C. ve ark.

content.beginner: Bakteriler her yerde, hatta uzay istasyonlarında bile yaşar. Enterococcus faecalis, insan bağırsaklarında yaygın olarak bulunan ve özellikle bağışıklık sistemi zayıflamış insanlarda enfeksiyonlara neden olabilen bir bakteri türüdür. Bilim insanları, orada hangi mikropların yaşadığını ve sağlık riski oluşturup oluşturmadıklarını görmek için Uluslararası Uzay İstasyonu'ndaki çeşitli yüzeylerden bakteri örnekleri topladılar. Birkaç E. faecalis suşu buldular ve genetik yapılarını analiz etmek için DNA dizileme kullandılar. Endişe verici bir şekilde, bu uzay istasyonu bakterileri antibiyotik direnci için genler taşıyordu ve bu da onları yaygın ilaçlarla tedavi etmeyi zorlaştırıyordu.
content.advanced: Bu kapsamlı genomik ve fenotipik araştırma, patojenik potansiyeli ve mürettebat sağlığı için etkilerini değerlendirmek amacıyla tüm genom dizileme, karşılaştırmalı genomik, antimikrobiyal duyarlılık testi, virülans faktörü profilleme ve enfeksiyon model testleri kullanarak birden fazla keif boyunca Uluslararası Uzay İstasyonu'ndaki çevresel yüzeylerden izole edilen Enterococcus faecalis suşlarını karakterize etmektedir. E. faecalis, insan GI sistem florasinin bir kommensali olan ancak aynı zamanda idrar yolu enfeksiyonları, bakteriyemi, endokardit ve yara enfeksiyonları dahil olmak üzere hastane enfeksiyonlarının %10-15'inden sorumlu fırsatcı bir patojen olan Gram-pozitif fakültatif bir anaeroptur.

title: Evaluation of in vitro macrophage differentiation during space flight.
author: Chelsea M., et al.

content.beginner: Macrophages are immune cells that act as the body's first line of defense, engulfing bacteria and infected cells. They develop from precursor cells called monocytes through a process called differentiation. This study examined whether microgravity affects how monocytes differentiate into macrophages. Researchers sent human monocytes to space aboard the Space Shuttle for 12 days and treated them with chemicals that trigger differentiation into macrophages. Comparing space-grown cells to Earth controls revealed significant differences: spaceflight macrophages showed altered shape, reduced ability to engulf particles (phagocytosis), and different patterns of surface proteins that help identify and attack invaders. Gene expression analysis found hundreds of immune-related genes were expressed differently in space. Most concerningly, the space macrophages were less effective at killing bacteria, suggesting spaceflight impairs immune cell development and function, potentially increasing astronaut infection risk during long missions.
content.advanced: This investigation evaluates the impact of authentic spaceflight microgravity on in vitro monocyte-to-macrophage differentiation, employing the Space Shuttle as an orbiting laboratory to culture human peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) under conditions not fully replicable in ground-based simulators. Human monocytes isolated from healthy donor blood (CD14+ selection, purity >95%) were cultured in specialized hardware (Group Activation Pack, GAP) aboard STS-134/135 missions for 12 days in RPMI-1640 + 10% autologous serum. Differentiation was induced via phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate (PMA, 100 ng/mL) treatment on flight day 3, with parallel ground controls in identical hardware with 1g centrifugation and static 1g controls. Post-flight analyses within 4 hours of landing included: (1) Morphological assessment via light and electron microscopy; (2) Flow cytometry immunophenotyping for differentiation markers (CD14, CD11b, CD68, HLA-DR, CD80, CD86, CD163); (3) Functional assays including phagocytosis (fluorescent E. coli bioparticles, zymosan), oxidative burst (dihydrorhodamine oxidation), and bacterial killing (live Staphylococcus aureus co-culture); (4) Microarray transcriptome profiling (Affymetrix Human Gene 1.0 ST); (5) Cytokine secretion profiling (Luminex multiplex assay for 27 cytokines/chemokines); (6) Signaling pathway activation (phospho-protein arrays). Morphological analysis revealed that spaceflight macrophages exhibited altered morphology: reduced cell spreading (projected area 35% smaller than controls, p<0.01), fewer filopodia/lamellipodia extensions (quantified via skeletonization analysis showing 48% reduction in process number), and less prominent rough ER/Golgi in TEM ultrastructure. Immunophenotyping demonstrated partially impaired differentiation: while CD14 expression appropriately downregulated (characteristic of monocyte-to-macrophage transition), expression of maturation markers CD11b and CD68 was 22-28% lower in flight samples (p<0.05). MHC class II (HLA-DR) expression, critical for antigen presentation, decreased 34% (p<0.01). Costimulatory molecules CD80/CD86 showed 25-30% reduced expression. Alternatively, the anti-inflammatory M2 marker CD163 was paradoxically upregulated 1.6-fold, suggesting skewing toward M2-like phenotype. Functional assessments revealed significant impairments: Phagocytosis assays showed flight macrophages internalized 42% fewer fluorescent E. coli particles (p<0.001) and 38% fewer zymosan particles (p<0.01) compared to controls, quantified via flow cytometry (% positive cells and mean fluorescence intensity). Time-lapse microscopy confirmed reduced speed of particle engulfment (12.3 min versus 7.8 min for 50% internalization). Oxidative burst capacity, measured as ROS production upon PMA stimulation, was reduced 47% (p<0.001), indicating impaired microbicidal capacity. Critically, bacterial killing assays using live S. aureus demonstrated that flight macrophages killed 35% fewer bacteria over 4-hour co-culture (CFU enumeration, p<0.01), representing functionally significant immunodeficiency. Transcriptomic analysis identified 1,247 differentially expressed genes (DEGs, FDR<0.05, |FC|>1.5) with Gene Ontology enrichment revealing downregulated pathways: 'phagocytosis' (34 genes including FcγR family, complement receptors), 'respiratory burst' (12 genes including NOX2, NCF1/2/4), 'antigen processing and presentation' (28 genes including HLA genes, cathepsins, proteasome subunits), 'cytoskeleton organization' (52 genes including Rho GTPases, formins, cofilin), and 'inflammatory response' (41 genes including pro-inflammatory cytokines, chemokines, TLR signaling components). Upregulated pathways included 'negative regulation of immune response' (anti-inflammatory genes like IL10, SOCS3), 'apoptosis' (pro-apoptotic BCL2 family members), and 'cellular stress responses'. Key transcription factors showed altered expression: PU.1 (master myeloid transcription factor) decreased 1.4-fold; NFκB target genes showed reduced activation; STAT1 (interferon-responsive) decreased while STAT3 (anti-inflammatory) increased. Cytokine profiling revealed dysregulated secretion: pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6) were reduced 40-55% in LPS-stimulated flight macrophages, while anti-inflammatory IL-10 increased 1.8-fold, confirming functional skewing toward immunosuppressive phenotype. Chemokines important for immune cell recruitment (IL-8, MCP-1, MIP-1α) decreased 35-60%. Signaling pathway analysis demonstrated reduced activation of pathways critical for macrophage function: phosphorylated ERK1/2 (MAPK pathway) reduced 43%, phospho-p38 decreased 38%, phospho-NF-κB p65 decreased 51%, and phospho-STAT1 decreased 45% upon LPS stimulation, indicating impaired innate immune signaling. Mechanistic investigations attributed defects to multiple factors: (1) Cytoskeletal disruption in microgravity impairs processes requiring actin remodeling (phagocytosis, migration, cell spreading); actin polymerization assays showed 32% reduced F-actin/G-actin ratio; (2) Altered mechanotransduction due to loss of gravitational force affects integrin signaling and focal adhesion formation (vinculin/paxillin localization disrupted); (3) Dysregulated calcium signaling (reduced Ca2+ flux upon stimulation) impacts multiple calcium-dependent immune functions; (4) Mitochondrial dysfunction (18% reduced ATP production, 1.9-fold elevated ROS) impairs energy-demanding processes. Importantly, comparison with rotating wall vessel (RWV) simulated microgravity partially replicated findings (~55% concordance in DEGs), but authentic spaceflight produced additional unique transcriptional signatures not seen in ground simulators, suggesting factors beyond microgravity (cosmic radiation, altered atmospheric composition, vibration) contribute. Time-course analysis revealed that defects manifested early (detectable by day 3) and persisted throughout 12-day culture, without adaptation or recovery. Post-flight recovery experiments showed that returning cells to 1g for 48 hours only partially restored function (phagocytosis recovered to 75% of normal, other functions remained impaired), indicating persistent epigenetic or structural changes. Clinical implications for spaceflight include: increased susceptibility to infections (wound infections, UTIs, respiratory infections documented in astronauts), impaired vaccination responses (antibody production depends on antigen-presenting cells), delayed wound healing (macrophages critical for tissue repair), and potential reactivation of latent infections (herpes viruses documented in astronauts). Countermeasure strategies could include: ex vivo immune cell conditioning before flight, pharmacological immune stimulators (TLR agonists, cytokines), nutritional interventions (vitamin D, omega-3 fatty acids supporting immune function), or artificial gravity via centrifugation. The research underscores that spaceflight immunodeficiency results not only from stress/radiation but also from fundamental cellular dysfunction at the level of immune cell development.

tr.title: Uzay Uçuşu Sırasında In Vitro Makrofaj Farklılaşmasının Değerlendirilmesi
tr.author: Chelsea M. ve ark.

content.beginner: Makrofajlar, bakterileri ve enfekte hücreleri yutarak vücudun ilk savunma hattı olarak hareket eden bağışıklık hücreleridir. Monosit adı verilen progenitor hücrelerden farklılaşma adı verilen bir süreç yoluyla gelişirler. Bu çalışma, mikro yerçekiminin monositlerin makrofajlara farklılaşmasını etkileyip etkilemediğini incelemiştir. Araştırmacılar, insan monositlerine 12 gün boyunca Uzay Mekiği'nde uzaya gönderdiler ve onları makrofajlara farklılaşmayı tetikleyen kimyasallarla tedavi ettiler. Uzayda yetişen hücrelerin Dünya kontrolleriyle karşılaştırılması önemli farkları ortaya çıkardı: uzay uçuşu makrofajları değişmiş şekil, azaltılmış parçacık yutma yeteneği (fagositoz) ve istilacıları tanımlamaya ve saldırmaya yardımcı olan yüzey proteinlerinin farklı paternleri gösterdi. Gen ifade analizi, yuz lerce bağışıklıkla ilgili genin uzayda farklı şekilde ifade edildiğini buldu. En endişe verici şekilde, uzay makrofajları bakterileri öldürmede daha az etkili oldu; bu, uzay uçuşunun bağışıklık hücresi gelişimini ve işlevini bozduğunu ve potansiyel olarak uzun görevler sırasında astronot enfeksiyon riskini artırdığını öne sürdü.
content.advanced: Bu araştırma, yer tabanlı simülatörlerde tam olarak tekrarlanamayan koşullarda insan periferik kan mononukleer hücrelerini (PBMC'leri) kültürlemek için Uzay Mekiği'ni yörüngedeki bir laboratüvar olarak kullanarak, gerçek uzay uçuşu mikro yerçekiminin in vitro monosit-makrofaj farklılaşması üzerindeki etkisini değerlendirmektedir. Sağlıklı donör kanından izole edilen insan monositleri (CD14+ seçimi, saflık >%95), STS-134/135 görevlerinde RPMI-1640 + %10 otolog serumda 12 gün boyunca özel donanımda (Grup Aktivasyon Paketi, GAP) kültür edilmiştir. Farklılaşma, uçuş günü 3'te forbol 12-miristat 13-asetat (PMA, 100 ng/mL) tedavisi yoluyla indüklenmiş ve aynı donanımda 1g santrifujla ve statik 1g kontrolleriyle paralel yer kontrolleri yapılmıştır. İnişten 4 saat içinde uçuş sonrası analizler şunları içeriyordu: (1) Işık ve elektron mikroskobu yoluyla morfolojik değerlendirme; (2) Farklılaşma belirteçleri (CD14, CD11b, CD68, HLA-DR, CD80, CD86, CD163) için akım sitometrisi immunüfenotipleme; (3) Fagositoz (floresan E. coli biyo-parçacıklar, zimosan), oksidatif patlama (dihidrorodamin oksidasyonu) ve bakteriyel öldürme (canlı Staphylococcus aureus birlikte kültür) dahil fonksiyonel testler; (4) Mikroarray transkriptom profilleme (Affymetrix Human Gene 1.0 ST); (5) Sitokin salınım profilleme (27 sitokin/kemokin için Luminex multipleks testi); (6) Sinyal yolu aktivasyonu (fosfo-protein dizileri). Morfolojik analiz, uzay uçuşu makrofajlarının değişmiş morfoloji sergilediğini ortaya çıkardı: azaltılmış hücre yayılması (projeksiyon alanı kontrollerden %35 daha küçük, p<0,01), daha az filopodi/lamellopodi uzantıları (iskelet analizi yoluyla nicelendirilmiş ve proses sayısında %48 azalma gösterilmiştir) ve TEM ultrayapısında daha az belirgin pürüzlü ER/Golgi. İmmunüfenotipleme, kısmen bozulmuş farklılaşma gösterdi: CD14 ifadesi uygun şekilde aşağı düzenlenirken (monosit-makrofaj geçişinin karakteristiği), olgunlaşma belirteçleri CD11b ve CD68'in ifadesi uçuş örneklerinde %22-28 daha düşüktü (p<0,05). Antijen sunumu için kritik olan MHC sınıf II (HLA-DR) ifadesi %34 azaldı (p<0,01). Ko-stimülatör moleküller CD80/CD86, %25-30 azaltılmış ifade gösterdi. Alternatif olarak, anti-enflamatuar M2 belirteci CD163 paradoksal olarak 1,6 kat yukarı düzenlendi ve M2 benzeri fenotipe doğru kayma önerdi. Fonksiyonel değerlendirmeler önemli bozulmalar ortaya çıkardı: Fagositoz testleri, uçuş makrofajlarının kontrollerle karşılaştırıldığında %42 daha az floresan E. coli parçacığı (p<0,001) ve %38 daha az zimosan parçacığı (p<0,01) içselleştirdiğini gösterdi. Zamana bağlı mikroskopi, parçacık içselleştirme hızının azaldığını doğruladı (%50 içselleştirme için 12,3 dakikaya karşın 7,8 dakika). PMA stimülasyonu üzerine ROS üretimi olarak ölçülen oksidatif patlama kapasitesi %47 azaldı (p<0,001), bu da bozulmuş mikrobisidal kapasiteyi gösteriyor. Kritik olarak, canlı S. aureus kullanan bakteriyel öldürme testleri, uçuş makrofajlarının 4 saatlik birlikte kültür üzerinde %35 daha az bakteri öldürdüğünü gösterdi (CFU sayımı, p<0,01), bu fonksiyonel olarak önemli bir immunü yetmezliği temsil ediyor.

title: Identification of critical host mitochondrion-associated genes during Ehrlichia chaffeensis infections
author: Kiersten A. N., et al.

content.beginner: Ehrlichia chaffeensis is a dangerous bacterium transmitted by ticks that causes human monocytic ehrlichiosis, a potentially fatal disease. This bacterium has an unusual strategy—it invades white blood cells and lives inside them by hijacking the cell's mitochondria (the powerhouse organelles that produce energy). Scientists wanted to understand which host cell genes related to mitochondria are critical for the bacteria to survive and multiply. Using RNA interference (a technique to turn off specific genes), researchers systematically tested which mitochondrial genes the bacteria depend on. They discovered that E. chaffeensis requires specific host genes involved in mitochondrial energy production, protein transport into mitochondria, and mitochondrial membrane maintenance. When these genes were silenced, bacterial replication decreased dramatically. This reveals that the bacteria essentially 'steal' the cell's energy-producing machinery to fuel their own growth. Understanding these dependencies could lead to new treatments targeting the host-pathogen interaction rather than the bacteria directly, potentially avoiding antibiotic resistance.
content.advanced: This systematic functional genomics investigation employs RNA interference screening to identify critical host mitochondrion-associated genes required for Ehrlichia chaffeensis intracellular survival and replication, providing mechanistic insights into obligate intracellular pathogen-organelle interactions. E. chaffeensis is a Gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacterium (Anaplasmataceae family) transmitted by Amblyomma americanum ticks, causing human monocytic ehrlichiosis characterized by fever, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, elevated hepatic enzymes, and potentially fatal complications (multi-organ failure, toxic shock-like syndrome, ARDS). The bacterium resides within membrane-bound inclusions (morulae) in monocytes/macrophages, manipulating host cell biology to create permissive replication niche. Prior studies indicated E. chaffeensis inclusion membranes closely associate with host mitochondria, with TEM revealing direct membrane contact sites, suggesting mitochondrial functions may be exploited. This study employed siRNA library targeting 152 human genes encoding mitochondrial proteins across functional categories: oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS complexes I-V), TCA cycle enzymes, mitochondrial protein import machinery (TIM/TOM complexes), mitochondrial dynamics (fusion/fission), mtDNA replication/transcription, metabolite transporters, and apoptosis regulators. THP-1 human monocytic cells were transfected with individual siRNAs using lipofection, followed 48 hours later by E. chaffeensis (Arkansas strain) infection at MOI=10. Bacterial load quantification at 48 and 72 hours post-infection employed: (1) qPCR amplifying E. chaffeensis 16S rRNA normalized to host GAPDH; (2) Immunofluorescence microscopy quantifying morulae per 100 cells; (3) Infectious progeny titration on naive THP-1 cells. Gene knockdown efficiency validated via qRT-PCR (>70% reduction for 89% of targets). Primary screen identified 47 genes whose silencing reduced E. chaffeensis replication >50% (Z-score < -2, p<0.01) without causing significant host cell death (<15% cytotoxicity). Secondary validation with alternative siRNA sequences confirmed 38 genes as bona fide hits. Functional categorization revealed enrichment in specific pathways: OXIDATIVE PHOSPHORYLATION: 14 genes encoding subunits of electron transport chain complexes significantly affected infection: Complex I (NDUFA9, NDUFB8, NDUFS3) silencing reduced bacterial load 55-68%; Complex III (UQCRC1, UQCRC2) knockdown decreased infection 62-70%; Complex IV (COX5A, COX6C) reduction impaired bacterial growth 58%; ATP synthase (ATP5A1, ATP5B) depletion reduced infection 72-80%. Pharmacological validation using rotenone (complex I inhibitor), antimycin A (complex III inhibitor), and oligomycin (ATP synthase inhibitor) dose-dependently reduced E. chaffeensis replication (IC50 values 50-250 nM), confirming OXPHOS dependence. Seahorse metabolic flux analysis demonstrated E. chaffeensis-infected cells exhibited 2.3-fold elevated oxygen consumption rates and 1.8-fold increased ATP production versus uninfected cells, with bacteria-containing inclusions co-localizing with areas of high mitochondrial activity. MITOCHONDRIAL PROTEIN IMPORT: Silencing components of TOM complex (TOMM20, TOMM40, TOMM70) reduced infection 45-60%, while TIM23 complex components (TIMM23, TIMM50) knockdown decreased bacterial load 52-68%. This suggests bacteria may secrete effector proteins requiring mitochondrial import, or rely on mitochondrial protein trafficking for inclusion membrane biogenesis. METABOLITE TRANSPORTERS: Knockdown of SLC25 family members was highly impactful: SLC25A4 (ANT1, adenine nucleotide translocase exchanging ATP/ADP) silencing reduced infection 78% (strongest hit); SLC25A3 (phosphate carrier) decreased load 68%; SLC25A5 (ANT2) reduced infection 71%. This indicates bacteria require continuous ATP export from mitochondria to cytoplasm/inclusion lumen. MITOCHONDRIAL DYNAMICS: Fusion proteins MFN1/MFN2 and OPA1 knockdown reduced infection 35-48%, suggesting bacteria benefit from elongated interconnected mitochondrial networks maximizing surface contact. Conversely, fission protein DRP1 silencing had minimal effect, consistent with preference for fused mitochondria. Live-cell imaging with MitoTracker revealed E. chaffeensis inclusions surrounded by mitochondria in tubular morphology versus fragmented mitochondria in uninfected cells. ANTI-APOPTOTIC GENES: BCL2, BCL-XL knockdown reduced infection 40-55%, indicating bacteria require host cell survival pathways to maintain replication niche. Pro-apoptotic BAX/BAK silencing had no effect, confirming anti-apoptotic activity is critical. Mechanistic studies employed combination approaches: Simultaneous knockdown of ATP5A1 + SLC25A4 produced synergistic reduction (92% decrease versus 72-78% individually), confirming bacteria require both ATP synthesis and export. ATP measurement in infected cells showed inclusion lumen ATP concentration reached 4.2 mM (similar to cytoplasmic 3.8 mM), achieved via mitochondrial provision and transporter-mediated import. Blocking experiments using bongkrekic acid (ANT inhibitor) reduced inclusion ATP to 1.1 mM and decreased bacterial replication 68%. E. chaffeensis effector identification: Immunoprecipitation of host mitochondrial proteins from infected cells followed by mass spectrometry identified three bacterial proteins (Ech_0230, Ech_0660, Ech_1143) associating with mitochondrial membranes. Ech_0660 showed homology to ATP/ADP carrier family and localized to inclusion membranes in contact with mitochondria, potentially functioning as bacterial ATP importer. Overexpression of dominant-negative Ech_0660 reduced bacterial replication 58%, confirming functional relevance. Clinical implications: Standard ehrlichiosis treatment uses doxycycline, but severe cases show variable responses and no alternative therapies exist for doxycycline-allergic patients. Host-directed therapies targeting mitochondrial functions could provide treatment options. However, concerns about mitochondrial toxicity require careful therapeutic window determination. Proof-of-concept experiments using metformin (complex I modulator) at clinically-achievable doses (10-50 μM) reduced E. chaffeensis load 40-60% without significant cytotoxicity, suggesting repurposing potential. The study reveals that obligate intracellular bacteria have evolved sophisticated mechanisms to exploit host organelles, particularly mitochondria, converting host cells into 'bacterial energy factories' by hijacking ATP generation and export machinery.

tr.title: Ehrlichia Chaffeensis Enfeksiyonları Sırasında Kritik Konak Mitokondri İlişkili Genlerin Tanımlanması
tr.author: Kiersten A. N. ve ark.

content.beginner: Ehrlichia chaffeensis, insan monositik ehrlichiosis adlı potansiyel olarak ölümcül bir hastalığa neden olan keneler tarafından taşınan tehlikeli bir bakteridir. Bu bakteri alışılmadık bir stratejiye sahiptir—beyaz kan hücrelerini istila eder ve hücrenin mitokondrisini (enerji üreten güç evi organellerini) kaçırarak içlerinde yaşar. Bilim insanları, bakterinin hayatta kalması ve çoğalması için mitokondri ile ilgili hangi konak hücre genlerinin kritik olduğunu anlamak istediler. RNA interferansı (belirli genleri kapatmak için bir teknik) kullanarak, araştırmacılar bakterinin hangi mitokondriyal genlere bağımlı olduğunu sistematik olarak test ettiler. E. chaffeensis'in mitokondriyal enerji üretimi, mitokondrilere protein taşınması ve mitokondriyal zar bakımı ile ilgili belirli konak genlerine ihtiyaç duyduğunu keşfettiler. Bu genler susturulduğunda, bakteriyel replikasyon dramatik bir şekilde azaldı. Bu, bakterilerin esasen kendi büyümelerini beslemek için hücrenin enerji üreten mekanizmasını 'çaldığını' ortaya koyuyor.
content.advanced: Bu sistematik fonksiyonel genomik araştırma, Ehrlichia chaffeensis hücre içi hayatta kalması ve replikasyonu için gerekli kritik konak mitokondri ile ilişkili genleri tanımlamak için RNA interferans tarama kullanır ve zorunlu hücre içi patojen-organel etkileşimleri hakkında mekanistik görüşler sağlar. E. chaffeensis, Amblyomma americanum keneleri tarafından taşınan, ateş, trombositopeni, lökopeni, yüksek karacigar enzimleri ve potansiyel olarak ölümcül komplikasyonlarla (multi-organ yetmezliği, toksik şok benzeri sendrom, ARDS) karakterize insan monositik ehrlichiosis'e neden olan Gram-negatif, zorunlu hücre içi bir bakteridir (Anaplasmataceae ailesi). Bakteri, monosit/makrofajlarda zar bağlı dahil etmeler (morulae) içinde yer alır ve izin verici replikasyon nişi oluşturmak için konak hücre biyolojisini manipüle eder. Önceki çalışmalar, E. chaffeensis dahil etme zarlarının konak mitokondrileri ile yakından ilişkili olduğunu, TEM'in doğrudan zar temas bölgelerini ortaya çıkardığını göstermiş ve mitokondriyal fonksiyonların istismar edilebileceğini öne sürmüştür. Bu çalışma, fonksiyonel kategoriler boyunca mitokondriyal proteinleri kodlayan 152 insan genini hedefleyen siRNA kütüphanesi kullanmıştır: oksidatif fosforilasyon (OXPHOS kompleksleri I-V), TCA döngüsü enzimleri, mitokondriyal protein ithalat mekanizması (TIM/TOM kompleksleri), mitokondriyal dinamikler (füzyon/fisyon), mtDNA replikasyonu/transkripsiyonu, metabolit taşıyıcıları ve apoptoz düzenleyicileri.

tr.author: Jeffrey M. G. ve ark.

title: Cytoskeletal configuration modulates mechanically induced changes in mesenchymal stem cell osteogenesis, morphology, and stiffness.
author: Henry J. D., et al.

content.beginner: This study investigated how the internal structure of stem cells (called the cytoskeleton) affects their ability to become bone cells when exposed to mechanical forces. The researchers found that the way the cytoskeleton is organized can change how stem cells respond to physical pressure and stress. When stem cells are exposed to mechanical forces, their cytoskeleton configuration influences whether they develop into bone cells, how their shape changes, and how stiff or flexible they become. The study showed that different cytoskeletal arrangements can either help or hinder the process of bone formation in stem cells. This research is important for understanding how to better control stem cell behavior for medical treatments, especially for bone regeneration and tissue engineering applications.

tr.title: Yük boşaltma ve yeniden yürüme sırasında genetik ve doku düzeyinde kas-kemik etkileşimleri.
tr.author: Henry J. D. ve ark.

title: Genetic and tissue level muscle-bone interactions during unloading and reambulation.
author: Fabio R. P., et al.

content.beginner: This study examined how muscles and bones interact with each other at both the genetic and tissue levels when animals experience reduced physical activity (unloading) and then return to normal activity (reambulation). The researchers investigated the complex relationship between muscle and bone tissues, focusing on how they communicate and influence each other's health and function. The study found that when physical activity is reduced, both muscles and bones undergo changes that affect each other, and when normal activity resumes, they work together to recover. The research revealed important genetic and molecular mechanisms that control how muscles and bones interact during these processes. This work is important for understanding how to prevent muscle and bone loss during periods of inactivity, such as bed rest or space travel, and how to promote recovery when normal activity resumes.

tr.title: Arka bacak yük boşaltımının neden olduğu osteosit apoptozu, osteosit RANKL üretimini ve ardından fare femurlarında kortikal ve trabeküler kemiğin rezorpsiyonunu tetiklemek için gereklidir.
tr.author: Fabio R. P. ve ark.

title: Osteocyte apoptosis caused by hindlimb unloading is required to trigger osteocyte RANKL production and subsequent resorption of cortical and trabecular bone in mice femurs.
author: Z. G. W., et al.

content.beginner: This study investigated how reduced physical activity (hindlimb unloading) in mice leads to bone loss by examining the role of osteocytes, which are specialized bone cells. The researchers found that when mice cannot use their hind legs normally, osteocytes (bone cells) begin to die through a process called apoptosis. This death of osteocytes triggers the production of a protein called RANKL, which signals other cells to break down bone tissue. The study showed that this process is necessary for the resorption (breakdown) of both cortical bone (the hard outer layer) and trabecular bone (the spongy inner layer) in mouse femurs. This research helps explain why people lose bone mass during periods of inactivity, such as bed rest or space travel, and could lead to new treatments to prevent bone loss in these situations.

tr.title: Embriyonik Kök Hücrelerin Embriyoid Cisimlere Karşı Yerçekimi Mekanostimülasyonuna Farklı Tek Hücre Yanıtları
tr.author: Z. G. W. ve ark.

title: Differential Single Cell Responses of Embryonic Stem Cells Versus Embryoid Bodies to Gravity Mechanostimulation
author: Rebecca A. M., et al.

content.beginner: This study compared how individual embryonic stem cells and embryoid bodies (clusters of stem cells) respond differently to gravity and mechanical stimulation. The researchers examined the responses of these cells at the single-cell level to understand how gravity affects their behavior and development. The study found that embryonic stem cells and embryoid bodies show different patterns of response when exposed to gravity and mechanical forces. Individual stem cells responded differently compared to when they were grouped together in embryoid bodies, suggesting that the cellular environment and organization play important roles in how cells sense and respond to mechanical stimuli. This research is important for understanding how gravity affects cell development and could help improve stem cell-based therapies and tissue engineering applications.

tr.title: Makrofajlar, Aspergillus fumigatus çimlenmesini ve nötrofil aracılı mantar öldürmeyi engeller.
tr.author: Rebecca A. M. ve ark.

title: Macrophages inhibit Aspergillus fumigatus germination and neutrophil-mediated fungal killing.
author: Janyce A. F., et al.

content.beginner: This study investigated how macrophages, which are immune cells that help fight infections, interact with Aspergillus fumigatus, a type of fungus that can cause serious infections in humans. The researchers found that macrophages can prevent the fungus from germinating (starting to grow) and can also interfere with the ability of neutrophils (another type of immune cell) to kill the fungus. The study showed that macrophages have both direct effects on the fungus and indirect effects by modifying how other immune cells respond to the infection. This research is important for understanding how the immune system fights fungal infections and could help develop better treatments for people with weakened immune systems who are more susceptible to these types of infections.

tr.title: Farklı Aspergillus fumigatus suşlarında spor ikincil metabolitlerinin UV-C korumasına ve virülansa katkıları değişir
tr.author: Janyce A. F. ve ark.

title: Contributions of spore secondary metabolites to UV-C protection and virulence vary in different Aspergillus fumigatus strains
author: Lori G., et al.

content.beginner: This study examined how different strains of Aspergillus fumigatus, a fungus that can cause infections, use secondary metabolites (chemical compounds produced by the fungus) to protect their spores from UV-C radiation and to cause disease. The researchers compared different strains of the fungus to see how they vary in their ability to protect themselves from harmful UV light and in their ability to cause infections. The study found that different strains produce different amounts and types of secondary metabolites, which affects both their resistance to UV-C radiation and their virulence (ability to cause disease). This research is important for understanding how fungi adapt to different environments and could help develop better treatments for fungal infections by targeting these protective mechanisms.

tr.title: Drosophila'da hemositlerin düzenlenmesi, benekli sitokrom b5 gerektirir.
tr.author: Lori G. ve ark.

title: Regulation of hemocytes in Drosophila requires dappled cytochrome b5.
author: John M. K., et al.

content.beginner: This study investigated how hemocytes (immune cells) in fruit flies (Drosophila) are regulated and found that a protein called dappled cytochrome b5 is required for this process. The researchers discovered that this specific protein plays a crucial role in controlling the development and function of hemocytes, which are important for the fly's immune system. The study showed that when dappled cytochrome b5 is not functioning properly, the regulation of hemocytes is disrupted, which can affect the fly's ability to fight infections and respond to immune challenges. This research helps us understand how immune cells are controlled in insects and could provide insights into similar processes in other organisms, including humans.

tr.title: Mikro yerçekiminde kırmızı ışığa yeni bir fototropik tepki ortaya çıkarıldı.
tr.author: John M. K. ve ark.

title: A novel phototropic response to red light is revealed in microgravity.
author: Sarah D. W., et al.

content.beginner: This study discovered a new type of plant response to red light that only appears when plants are grown in microgravity (near-zero gravity) conditions, such as in space. The researchers found that plants show a phototropic response (bending toward light) to red light when they are in microgravity, which is different from their normal behavior on Earth. This novel response was not observed under normal gravity conditions, suggesting that gravity plays an important role in how plants normally respond to different types of light. The study helps us understand how plants adapt to space environments and could be important for growing plants in space for future space missions or space colonies.

tr.title: Karşılaştırmalı transkriptomik, uzay uçuşu sırasında fidelerde hücre duvarı organizasyonunda ve stres yanıtında değişiklikler olduğunu gösterir
tr.author: Sarah D. W. ve ark.

title: Plant cell proliferation and growth are altered by microgravity conditions in spaceflight.
author: John M. K., et al.

content.beginner: This study investigated how plant cells behave differently when grown in space under microgravity conditions compared to on Earth. The researchers found that the way plant cells divide (proliferate) and grow is significantly altered when plants are exposed to the near-zero gravity environment of space. The study showed that microgravity affects various aspects of plant cell biology, including how fast cells divide, how they organize themselves, and how they develop into different types of plant tissues. This research is important for understanding how plants adapt to space environments and could help develop better methods for growing plants in space, which will be essential for long-term space missions and potential space colonization.

tr.title: Uluslararası Uzay İstasyonunda mikro yerçekimi ve kesirli yerçekiminde Arabidopsis thaliana'nın fototropizmi.
tr.author: John M. K. ve ark.

title: Phototropism of Arabidopsis thaliana in microgravity and fractional gravity on the International Space Station.
author: Sarah D. W., et al.

content.beginner: This study examined how Arabidopsis thaliana (a small flowering plant commonly used in research) responds to light (phototropism) under different gravity conditions on the International Space Station. The researchers compared the plant's light-seeking behavior in microgravity (near-zero gravity) and fractional gravity (reduced gravity) to understand how gravity affects this important plant response. The study found that Arabidopsis plants show different phototropic responses depending on the gravity level they experience, with microgravity and fractional gravity producing distinct patterns of light-directed growth. This research helps us understand how plants adapt their growth and development to different gravitational environments, which is important for growing plants in space and understanding how gravity influences plant biology.

tr.title: Karşılaştırmalı transkriptomik, uzay uçuşu sırasında fidelerde hücre duvarı organizasyonunda ve stres yanıtında değişiklikler olduğunu gösterir
tr.author: Sarah D. W. ve ark.

title: Light and gravity signals synergize in modulating plant development
author: John M. K., et al.

content.beginner: This study investigated how light and gravity signals work together to control plant development and growth. The researchers found that these two environmental signals don't work independently but instead combine and interact with each other to influence how plants grow and develop. The study showed that light and gravity signals synergize, meaning they work together in a way that produces effects greater than the sum of their individual effects. This interaction between light and gravity is important for various aspects of plant development, including how plants orient themselves, how they grow toward light sources, and how they respond to their environment. Understanding this synergy is crucial for growing plants in space where gravity is reduced, and could help develop better agricultural techniques on Earth.
